nodes.bodyText: Please rename to follow Java convention CamelCase. To make it shorter, I think you can remove prefix testApplyJDBCDateFormat_, ex. testEpochSecond(), testBasicDate() etc.

nodes.bodyText: remove unused code?
Removed
Please add JavaDoc for new class and its public methods.
Added JavaDoc comments to new class & public methods
Thanks!
I think you should pick columns of DATE type into a Set in your constructor to save this for loop. Otherwise it runs for each row in the result set.
Now saving date columns in constructor (saving as List, since it seems that Sets cannot be iterated through with this foreach syntax
Thanks for the changes! But I assume a Set<String> with all field names of DATE type is sufficient right? Why original Column saved in a list with for-loop ran for each row in result set?
Oh yes, this makes sense! Since all I need is the name of the column. Will make this change
Addressed (now only storing a Set<String> for date column names)
I think you may not need to touch this class or the LocalClusterState either. Because LocalClusterState has the mapping, you can just use it outside or in your new added Formatter class.
Now fetching information from LocalClusterState in my Formatter class
Any chance to avoid the changes in LocalClusterState? It is a global state which can not be used for state per query.
Moved changes out of LocalClusterState
As my other comment said, this is not thread safe.
Moved changes out of LocalClusterState
What is the difference between DateFormat.Date and FORMAT_DOT_DATE?
No difference; changed to now reference DateFormat.DATE instead

How does multiple date format covered?
https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/date.html#multiple-date-formats
Currently not handled; will add handling & testing for this
Added handling & tests for multiple formats

Is it possible the columnFormat is not included in the DateFormat? For example, custom-date-formats, https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/mapping-date-format.html#custom-date-formats
Yeah, this does look to be a possible case. Will add handling & testing for this
Updated implementation & added tests for handling custom formats
